guide.abstract: The Gentoo Documentation Project is an official Gentoo Linux project devoted to the complete and concise documentation of Gentoo Linux.

section.title: What we do, and who we are

body.p: The Gentoo Documentation Project (GDP) is an official project of the Gentoo Linux project responsible for the creation and maintenance of all official Gentoo Linux documentation. The GDP is not a closed team of any sorts, but instead an open community commited to critiqing, and possibly integrating, viable user documentation.

The Gentoo Documentation Project was formed to address the need of complete documentation for Gentoo GNU/Linux. In doing so, the GDP team is commited to the creation and maintenance of clear, concise, and original documentation. We will protect our users and developers by the use of free and open licensing on all documentation. The GDP is commited to remaining a free and open project, and will abide by the Social Contract set forth by Gentoo GNU/Linux.

body.p: The current active subprojects in the Gentoo Documentation Project are:

tr.ti: Core documentation, such as the arch specific installation guides, and the Desktop Guide, are maintained in this project. Project members will work closely with many other teams in the Gentoo Linux hierarchy to make absolutely positive that our most important documentation is one-hundred percent correct and up to date.
The core of the GDP team, most of the work in this subproject relates to the maintenance and incorportation of application centric documentation.
The Portage documentation, rc-scripts guide, and other Gentoo specific documentation is covered under this subproject. The goal of this subproject is to completely document what makes Gentoo, Gentoo.

As Gentoo continues to grow, international documentation will be key to communicating with our diverse user base. The translators will make sure that all Gentoo documentation is translated in a timely fashion.
The goal of this subproject is to document everything concerning the GDP Project itself. This includes the GDP Policy, XML Guide, ...

body.p: The current planned subprojects in the Gentoo Documentation Project are:

tr.ti: GDP documentation needs to be printer compatible. This subproject will completely oversee the planning and implementation of making GDP documentation printer friendly.

In order for developers to easily write documentation concerning their project, the Gentoo Documentation Project provides them with a WiKi site on which they can develop the documentation. When that document is finished, the GDP Team can start converting the document into GuideXML
There are many packages in the Portage tree that need man pages.

body.p: Whenever a Gentoo Documentation Team Member thinks he's up to it (and it doesn't harm his other responsibilities), the subprojects can become active.
In order for the GDP to become a succesfull project, we need many people playing many roles in a coherent way. This includes documentation writers, reviewers, translators, editors, contributors, etc.

The team is compromised of Members and Contributors. Members can have direct access to the source of a subproject and actively participate in the development of documentation. Contributors improve the project through submission of documents, etc to the Members. The number of Contributors is unbounded.

body.p: Listing the enormous amount of contributors to the Gentoo Documentation Project would require one very huge page. We thank all contributors (both retired and active) for their enormous help to the project.
The Gentoo Documentation Project makes intensive use of the gentoo-doc@gentoo.org mailinglist. On this mailinglist discussions about documentation, subprojects, translations and more pass by.

To subscribe to this mailinglist, send an empty e-mail to gentoo-doc-subscribe@gentoo.org. Once subscribed you can post to it by sending an e-mail to gentoo-doc@gentoo.org. To unsubscribe from the list, send an empty e-mail to gentoo-doc-unsubscribe@gentoo.org. There is also an online archive on news.gmane.org.

To participate in the Gentoo Documentation Project first join the mailing list at gentoo-doc@gentoo.org. Then ask if there are plans to support something that you are interested in, propose a new subproject that you are interested in, or choose one of the planned subprojects to work on. You may talk to the developers and users in the IRC channel #gentoo-doc on irc.freenode.net for more information or just to chat about the project or any subprojects. If you don't have the ability to actively help by contributing work we will always need editors to maintain the quality and accuracy of the overall product. All development, editing, and productive comments and feedback will be greatly appreciated.
